title: How to Curl Ribbon with Scissors

steps.title: Purchase a roll of curling ribbon.
steps.content: Purchase a roll of curling ribbon. You can find plastic curling ribbons in most craft stores and gift wrapping aisles. It’s typically available in large spools of 1 ⁄ 2 in (1.3 cm) wide ribbon. Smaller rolled bundles of 1 ⁄ 4 in (0.64 cm) wide ribbon are also available. Curling ribbon can have a smooth or crimped texture. Narrow curling ribbon intended for gift wrapping sometimes comes in shiny or metallic holiday colors. Fabric ribbons can’t be curled with scissors. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Measure out a length of curling ribbon.
steps.content: Measure out a length of curling ribbon. When you’re practicing, experiment with different ribbon lengths to see how short they’ll get once curled. If you want to create a specific length, measure out more than you think you’ll need. As a rule of thumb, an uncurled strand of the ribbon should be 3 to 6 times longer than the final curled strand. [2] X Research source Start with longer strands if you plan on making tight curls. For loose curls, you can use shorter strands.

steps.title: Cut the ribbon.
steps.content: Cut the ribbon. Use craft scissors to cut the ribbon from the spool. It’s ok to cut a narrow ribbon straight across so that the ends are squared off. The blunt end won’t be noticeable once you’ve finished assembling a curly bundle. But you can cut the ends of the wider ribbon on a 45-degree angle to create an attractive finish. [3] X Research source You can always go back and trim the curled strands of ribbon. This way you can make them shorter, or you can give them a different edge finish.

steps.title: Identify the natural curl of the ribbon.
steps.content: Identify the natural curl of the ribbon. If your curling ribbon came on a spool or a rolled bundle, it will instinctively curl in one direction. Determine which way it’s curling and plan to add curls in the same direction. For instance, if the ribbon was rolled around a spool in a clockwise manner, it will form a loose clockwise curl even when you cut it off. But if you flip it over, it will have a counter-clockwise curl. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Grip a strand of ribbon in your non-dominant hand.
steps.content: Grip a strand of ribbon in your non-dominant hand. Whether your ribbon is already tied onto a gift box or if it’s a loose strand, firmly grip the base of the ribbon with your index finger and thumb. [5] X Research source Use your non-dominant hand for this, so your dominant hand is free to manipulate the scissors. If you’re right-handed, hold the ribbon in your left hand and the scissors in your right hand.

steps.title: Hold an open pair of craft scissors in your dominant hand.
steps.content: Hold an open pair of craft scissors in your dominant hand. Carefully separate the blades. Grip your hands around the handles as well as the pivot point to keep the scissors open and stable. Position the scissors parallel to the floor or table, and make sure the blades are pointing towards your non-dominant hand. [6] X Research source You can use any type of straight-bladed craft scissors, but note that sharper metal blades will create tighter curls. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Place the dull side of the ribbon against the blade.
steps.content: Place the dull side of the ribbon against the blade. Some curling ribbons are glossy or metallic on one side and dull on the reverse. Place the dull side flat on top of the inside of the lower scissor blade. Hold the ribbon down firmly using your thumb on your dominant hand. [8] X Research source If your curling ribbon is the same on both sides, that’s ok. Just curl the ribbon in the direction of its natural curl. If you’re following the natural curl of the ribbon, the loose end of the ribbon should be wrapping over and around the scissors (rather than up and away from the scissors) in this position. The glossy side will end up on the outside of the curl and the dull side will remain on the inside.

steps.title: Extend the ribbon over the scissor blade at a right angle.
steps.content: Extend the ribbon over the scissor blade at a right angle. [9] X Research source You should still be holding the base of the ribbon firmly with your non-dominant hand. Above the base, it should be pointing directly upwards. Make sure the horizontal scissor blade is perpendicular to this vertical length of ribbon, and that the rest is going directly over the scissor blade, parallel to the ground or table. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Pull the scissors up and out along the dull side of the ribbon.
steps.content: Pull the scissors up and out along the dull side of the ribbon. Keep the lower scissor blade in contact with the ribbon and maintain a firm grip on the base of the ribbon. Use your dominant hand to pull the scissors up and away from the base. The open blades will be facing towards you as you do this. [11] X Research source During this process, you are slightly stretching out the outside of the ribbon and encouraging the inside to shrink in. As a result, the plastic will adopt a curly structure. [12] X Research source Pull the scissors out and away from your body as a safety precaution. While you should keep an eye on the blades, refrain from bringing your face too close to the scissors.

steps.title: Work slowly and with even pressure to draw the blade across the ribbon.
steps.content: Work slowly and with even pressure to draw the blade across the ribbon. Hold the ribbon against the scissor blade with your thumb as you go, maintaining a consistent, moderately firm tension. Rather than pulling the scissors in one fast motion, keep your motions relatively slow and gradual. [13] X Research source If you go too slow, you might accidentally flatten out the ribbon. Practice with different speeds to find the ideal pace that produces the best curl.

steps.title: Draw the blade across the entire length of the ribbon.
steps.content: Draw the blade across the entire length of the ribbon. To get an even, one-directional curl, start at the base and pull the scissor blade across the full length of the ribbon until you reach the very end. Once you reach the end, release the ribbon and you’ll see it spiral up into a curl. [14] X Research source For very long strands of ribbon, you can work on curling short segments at a time. Each time, start where you left off.

steps.title: Repeat the process to get a tighter curl.
steps.content: Repeat the process to get a tighter curl. If you missed part of the ribbon, or if you want to tighten the curl, you can run the scissor blade along the dull side of the ribbon once again. Work in the same direction during a second or third pass. [15] X Research source If the ribbon starts to shred or flatten out, discard it and start again with a new piece. By going over part or all of the ribbon multiple times, you may end up with an irregular curl formation. [16] X Research source This may not matter if you’re creating a dense bundle of curled ribbons, though!

steps.title: Create a bundle of multiple strands of ribbons before curling them.
steps.content: Create a bundle of multiple strands of ribbons before curling them. If you’re wrapping a gift, use multiple strands of ribbon to tie up the box. Secure the ends in a knot at the top. Leave the loose ends long so that they create a voluminous curl. Cut some additional strands to the same length as the loose ends, and tie these over the knot as well to create a fuller-looking bunch of curls. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Curl a series of loose strands of ribbon and secure them together.
steps.content: Curl a series of loose strands of ribbon and secure them together. Use 1 color or many colors to create an attractive bundle of curls. After you’ve curled them all, line them up parallel to each other. Find the center point and create a single knot there. Or, you can knot them together at one end for a curled ribbon tassel. [18] X Research source When creating a knot, you might be worried about ruining the curls. Luckily, curling ribbon is pretty resilient. Once it’s been curled you’ll have a hard time flattening it out!

steps.title: Tie the bundle to an anchor point using a short length of ribbon.
steps.content: Tie the bundle to an anchor point using a short length of ribbon. If you’re attaching the ribbon bundle onto something that has an anchor point of some sort, such as a gift box that already has some ribbon around it, or a gift tag with a hole at the top, knotting is the best way to secure it. Cut a small length of the same curling ribbon and wrap it around both the anchor point and the ribbon. Tie a double knot and trim the ends short. You won’t even notice it! [19] X Research source Curled ribbons also look pretty dangling from balloons and party chairs. Tie them on using a small length of ribbon in a similar manner. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Attach the ribbon bundle onto something else by taping or stapling it.
steps.content: Attach the ribbon bundle onto something else by taping or stapling it. If you’re attaching the ribbons onto a paper craft project or another surface, place a short, narrow length of adhesive tape over the knotted part of the bundle and secure it onto the object’s surface. [21] X Research source Or, you can punch a staple through the ribbon bundle’s central knot and the paper. Make sure both of the ends of the staple have gone completely through the ribbon so it doesn’t come loose.

steps.title: Arrange the curls in an attractive design.
steps.content: Arrange the curls in an attractive design. If you’ve used lots of strands of ribbon, you can fluff them around to achieve a loose, bouncy explosion of curls or a tight, orderly arrangement. Tuck different strands of ribbon over and under other ones. Blend together different colors and make sure the glossy side faces out. Hide the loose ends in the bundle, or pull them out and trim them at a 45-degree angle. [22] X Research source Most importantly, have fun arranging your ribbon curls! Wind individual strands around your index finger and gently elongate them to re-orient curls that may have gotten twisted up.
